questions.Name: Do you easily communicate expectations verbally to your management?
Do you easily communicate expectations verbally to your co-workers?
Do you prefer to communicate verbally to your team and management?
I tend to say what I think, without worrying about how the other person perceives it. I assume that we'll be able to discuss it later.
Do you feel comfortable asking for feedback?
Do you feel comfortable communicating when you’re very busy and need assistance?
Do you prefer to communicate writtenly to your team and management?
Do you respond to emails within a day of receiving them?
When I write a memo, email, or other document, I give all of the background information and detail I can to make sure that my message is understood.
Before I send a message I think about the best way to communicate it to the audience.
I try to help people understand the underlying concepts behind the point I am discussing. This reduces misconceptions and increases understanding of my message.
Do you think your environment affects how you communicate in the workplace?
Do you contact management verbally/written when you have questions?
Do you contact your co-workers verbally/written when you have questions?
If I don't understand something, I won't keep this to myself and figure it out later.
If I am unsure about a given task, I find it comfortable to ask for help.
I am not afraid to be direct with someone, even if they think I am being rude.
Do you prepare and practice your presentations?
Do you feel comfortable presenting without looking at slides?
Do you agree that you can eloquently and clearly present your thoughts to upper management and co-workers?
Do you feel comfortable working in person with unfamiliar coworkers?
Do you find it easy for you to experience a change in your workspace?
Do you handle unexpected situations well ?
I am never thrown off by tasks regarding subjects which I don't know.
I enjoy unfamiliar situations.
Do you feel comfortable working in person with unfamiliar coworkers?
I do not experience an increase in stress levels when tasks begin to pile up
I am easily able to seperate my personal life stress (family, relationships) from my work stresses (projects, deadlines)
I would prefer to work in a loud environment
Unfamiliariies never create stress in the workplace for me
I would enjoy having a close relationship with my boss
I would prefer to work in a fast paced environment
I am very willing to learn new methods in the workplace
I am willing to take on tasks even if I have never done them
I am flexible in my working hours when deadlines become pressing
I would prefer to work in a private environment where others cannot see my screen
Having little to no power in the workplace is uncomfortable for me
My work does not affect my personal life
I am comforable with working from home when necessary
I am able to handle crisis situaions without issue
If I mess up, I refrain from saying self-deprecating things, such as "I am such a loser", "Stupid, stupid, stupid", or "I can't do anything right".
I do not get easily stressed out or agitated at work.
I remain civil to people even if I really dislike them.
I can stay calm under pressure.
I handle setbacks effectively.
I can freely take responsibility for my mistakes.
I utilize criticism and other feedback for growth.
I remain positive in negative situations.
I adjust my behavior depending on who I’m interacting with.
I do not become defensive when criticized.
I always feel comfortable asking for something that I want (e.g. a raise, more respect at the office, etc.).
When I need to do something difficult or unpleasant, I find it easy to motivate myself to get started.
If I'm not good at something right away, I'd rather spend more time working on it than quit.
I feel like I live in the present moment (rather than just going through the motions of daily life...such as running on auto-pilot).
I am satisfied with my work even if it goes unrecognized.
I manage anxiety, stress, anger, and fear in pursuit of a goal.
I can listen to others without jumping to judgment.
My employer’s values coincide with my own.
I tend to assume the best of people (rather than the worst).
I recognize how my behavior affects others around me.
I agree that it is that I should possess/acquire interpersonal skills
The clothes I wear would never offend another person.
My hair is well groomed and my fingernails are clean and nicely trimmed.
I display the same standards of behavior that I expect from other people.
I wear the appropriate shoes to work.
I say "thank you" to the people I work with.
I think about how others perceive a problem or issue.
I come into work with a positive attitude.
I do not wear excessive perfume or colonge.
When other people do something different from the way I would do it, I avoid being critical of them.
I inject my own ideas into the mix rather than go alone with others’ decisions.
If someone gives me a gift or does me a favor, I send them a thank you note.
While actively talking with someone, I wait to compose my answer until they have finished speaking.
People who know me would describe me as cheerful and friendly.
i don’t speak first, and think later.
I don’t get bored with conversations easily and perceive that most people have something interesting to say.
I don’t interrupt the speaker if I disagree with a statement they have made.
I ask for help when I do not know how to do something.
I am not under the influence of drugs or alcohol when I am at work.
I am accepting and open to others’ differences (in gender, culture, beliefs, etc.)
The success of the business is important to you.
There are no negative implications to the decisions you make at work.
You try to go beyond the scope of the work you have to do.
Your paycheck is not the only motivation you have for working at Verve.
You believe that you can thrive and grow professionally by working at Verve.
You have a positive attitude while working at Verve.
You feel determined to finish your work on time.
You avoid being idle and wasting time at work.
You share credit for other people’s contributions on projects.
You try to be as accurate as you can when doing your job.
You follow the directions you are given on a project.
You tell management about what issues you are having.
You feel accountable for the results of your work.
You communicate honestly to your peers and managers.
You have the company’s best interest in mind while making decisions.
You trust the people you work with at Verve.
You think that people at Verve trust you.
People can depend on you when they need help.
You follow Verve regulations.
You are transparent about about the decisions you make while working.
